title: Form of equipotential earthing system
fullText:
An EP earthing system shall only be provided with one EP junction.
All points associated with a cardiac-protected electrical area that are required to be connected to the EP earthing system shall be earthed via the EP junction or one of its nodes in accordance with Clauses 4.4.2.4 to 4.4.2.7.
The EP earthing system may have a number of separate nodes at strategic locations connected to the EP junction, as shown in Figure 8, provided that the following requirements are met:
(a)	Each node is individually connected to the EP junction by insulated conductors with a maximum resistance of 0.01 Ω.
(b)	Each node is accessible and its location identified by labelling.
(c)	Each node is fully insulated or isolated from contact with structural metal.
(d)	Each node is numbered and identifies the location of the EP junction.
(e)	Each conductor installed between a node and the EP junction is numbered at the EP junction to identify the node.
(f)	The EP junction identifies the number of nodes connected.
NOTES:
1	The arrangement referred to above may be used to limit the length of individual EP earth conductors in large cardiac-protected electrical areas with many patient locations.
2	To measure the resistance, disconnecting one end of the conductor installed between the EP junction and each node and measuring its resistance using a four-terminal milliohm measuring device.
3	The earthing conductor of a multi-core supply cable from a switchboard to an imaging system may be used as a return earth providing that the EP junction is connected to the main earthing terminal/bus of the imaging system with a conductor having a maximum resistance of 0.01 Ω (see Figure 9).
